div.p: Literally "Let it be printed" (Latin, from imprimere, "to print").

Used originally by ecclesiastical authorities or secular licensors to approve the publication of a book after examination of its contents, the term came into general use in both German and English as an indication by an author to a publisher that the typography and make-up of a work was ready for printing.

Schenker gave his imprimatur to all of his works, with J. G. Cotta, Universal Edition, and Drei Masken Verlag, after having examined and corrected first the galley-proofs then one or two sets of page-proofs. Sometimes he would ask for a further set, not necessarily of the whole work, before being willing to give his go ahead, as in for example this case with Beethovens Neunte Sinfonie: Gatherings 9, 10, 12, and 13 get their imprimatur; as to gathering 11, unfortunately some pages are in a state of disorder as a result of carelessness; consequently, I would prefer to see yet a further proof, just to be on the safe side. (WSLB 106, April 14, 1912).
